Package ds.util

This package provides the interfaces and collection classes that are developed in the book.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Collection<T> The root interface in the collection hierarchy.
Comparator<T> A comparison function, which imposes a total ordering on some collection of objects.
Graph<T> An interface that defines access and update methods for the vertices and edges in a direct weighted graph.
Iterable<T> Implementing this interface allows a collection object with an iterator to be the target of an enhanced "foreach" statement.
Iterator<T> An iterator is a generalized object to scan a collection.
List<T> A collection of elements that are stored by position (also known as a sequence).
ListIterator<T> An iterator for lists that allows the programmer to traverse the list in either direction and modify the list during iteration.
Map<K,V> A Map object maps keys to values; a map cannot contain duplicate keys and each key can map to at most one value.
Map.Entry<K,V> A map entry (key-value pair).
OrderedMap<K,V> An interface that extends Map by defining the methods firstKey and lastKey that return the minimum and maximum key in the collection of key-value pairs; an iterator scan the entries in the collection is ascending order of their key.
OrderedSet<T> An interface that extends Set by defining the methods first and last that return the minimum and and maximum value in the collection; an iterator scans the elements in the collection is ascending order.
PQueue<T> A collection designed for holding elements prior to their execution.
Queue<T> A collection designed for holding elements prior to their execution.
Set<T> A set is a collection that contains no duplicate elements; that is, sets contain no pair of elements obj1 and obj2 such that obj1.equals(obj2).
Stack<T> A collection designed for holding elements prior to their execution.
 

Class Summary
ALStack<T> An implemetation of the Stack interface using an ArrayList collection as the underlying storage structure.
ArrayList<T> An array-based implementation of the List interface.
Arrays This class contains methods for searching, sorting, and listing the elements in an array.
AVLTree<T> This class is a balanced binary tree that implements the Collection interface AVL tree single and double rotation methods.
Bag<T> This class implements the Collection interface as a user-specified finite array; random access to an element is provided by the grab method.
BinaryTree This class contains methods for the classic binary tree traversal algorithms, console and graphical tree display methods, and miscellaneous methods to build binary trees.
BitArray This class has objects that support bit handling for a large array of bytes.
BQueue<T> This class implements a finite queue using a circular queue model to store and retrieve elements.
DiGraph<T> An instance of the DiGraph class is a directed weight graph that implements the Graph interface.
DiGraphs<T> This class contains static methods for the classical graph scanning algorithms, topological sort, strong components, and path optimization.
DNode<T> DNode objects are the elements in a doubly linked list; they have three fields that designate the value and links to the successor node and to the predecessor node.
DNodes This class contains methods for adding and removing a node from a doubly linked list; it also has the method toString that describes the elements in the list.
Greater<T> A Comparator that imposes a total ordering on objects that implement Comparable; the comparison is the ">" relation where the ordering of elements proceeds from larger to smaller.
Hash<T> This class implements the Collection interface using a hash table as the underlying storage structure.
HashMap<K,V> This class implements the Map interface using a hash table as the underlying storage structure.
HashSet<T> This class implements the Set interface, backed by a hash table (actually a HashMap instance).
HeapPQueue<T> An unbounded priority queue based an a priority heap.
Heaps This class contains the heap methods popHeap,pushHeap, and heapsort.
InorderIterator<T> This class is partial implementation of an Iterator that produces an iterative inorder scan of the elements in a binary tree specified by a TNode reference root.
Less<T> A Comparator that imposes a total ordering on objects that implement Comparable; the comparison is the "<" relation where the ordering of elements proceeds from smaller to larger.
LinkedList<T> The LinkedList class implements of the List interface using a doubly-linked list as the underlying storage structure.
LinkedQueue<T> This class implements the Queue interface using a LinkedList object by composition.
Node<T> Node objects are the elements in a singly linked list; they have two fields that designate the value and a link to the successor node.
Nodes This class contains a method to remove a node from a singly linked list; it also has the method toString that describes the elements in the list.
OrderedList<T> This class extends LinkedList by overriding add to insert a new item in order.
RBTree<T> This class implements the Collection interface using a red-black tree as the underlying storage structure.
Sets This class contains static methods for creating the union, intersection, and difference of two sets as well as determining the "subset" relation between two sets.
STree<T> This class implements the Collection interface using a binary search tree as the underlying storage structure.
TNode<T> TNode objects are the elements in a binary tree; they have three fields that designate the value and links to the left and right child.
TreeMap<K,V> An STree implementation of the OrderedMap interface.
TreeSet<T> An implementation of the OrderedSet using STNode elements and binary search tree (STree algorithms.
 

Enum Summary
VertexColor An enum class that defines constant colors that descibe visit properties for a vertex in a graph.
 

Package ds.util Description

This package provides the interfaces and collection classes that are developed in the book. The interfaces describe the collection types that form a collection framework for the study of data structures; the collection classes implement the interfaces. The following is a listing of the main interfaces and collections classes that are used in most data structure applications.

Interface Collection Class
Collection Bag
List ArrayList     LinkedList     OrderedList
Set HashSet
    OrderedSet TreeSet
Map HashMap
    OrderedMap TreeMap
Graph DiGraph
Adapter Structures  
    Stack ALStack
    Queue LinkedQueue     BQueue
    PQueue HeapPQueue

The book develops a series of algorithms to search and sort an array.  The algorithms are defined as static methods in the Arrays class. Implementing collection classes require underlying storage structures. In this book, we use Node and DNode objects to create singly and doubly linked lists. Key algorithms to access, update, and display elements in the lists are included as static methods in the classes Nodes and DNodes respectively.  Binary trees are non-linear structures that stores elements as nodes emanating from a root. The elements are TNode objects. An extensive list of algorithms describe tree scanning operations and tree applications.  The algorithms are static methods in the BinaryTree class. The DiGraphs class is a series of static methods that present classical graph algorithms.

For applications that store elements by key, we use the TreeSet/TreeMap and HashSet/HashMap classes.  These collection objects use binary search trees and hash tables for their underlying storage structures.  Developing your understanding of the design and implementation of these structures is an important objective in the book. We focus the discussion by developing the binary search tree class STree and the hash table class Hash. By balancing nodes in a search tree class, we improve the efficiency of the access and update methods including insertion and deletion of elements.  The classical AVLTree class and the RBTree (red-black) class introduce two separate balancing strategies.  The classes that define Hoffman compression and decompression operations use BitArray objects to store code as a series of binary digits.

Modern data structures use the concept of an iterator to create a generalized scanning technique to visit elements in a collection.  The discussion of iterators uses the Iterator and ListIterator interfaces.  The InorderIterator class is an implementation of the Iterator interface for binary trees.  Java uses an enhanced for statement as an alternative to an iterator when accessing elements in a collection.  The enhanced for statement requires that the collection class must implement the Iterable interface.

Objects such as numbers, characters, strings, and time can be compared with the "less than", "equal to" and "greater than" relations.  The comparison uses a natural ordering among the objects.  A "less than" or "greater than" relation can be defined in a Comparator object which is passed as an argument for methods that sort an array or handle elements in a heap.  This generalizes the methods and allows them, for instance, to sort an array in either ascending or descending order.  In this package we define the Comparator interface and two special classes Less and Greater whose instances provide a "less than" or a "greater than" compare() method respectively.
